TEXT.TEXTVALUE: Point the mouse to each requirement of the experiment to know the name/click the “continue” button to start the experiment.
notext
A butter paper is taken from the lab bench.
The butter paper is placed on the weighing balance and the value is tared to zero.
The butter paper is placed on the weighing balance and the value is tared to zero.
A spatula is taken from the lab bench.
A small amount of Trypticase powder is then taken from the bottle using the spatula.
The weight of trypticase is adjusted to 1 g.
The butter paper with trypticase powder is then taken out from the weighing balance.
The trypticase powder is then transferred into a conical flask.
The trypticase powder is then transferred into a conical flask.
With a clean spatula, a small amount of glucose powder is taken from the bottle.
The glucose powder is then taken to the weighing balance and it is transferred into a clean butter paper. The weight of the glucose is adjusted to 0.5 g.
The butter paper with glucose powder is then taken out from the weighing balance.
The glucose powder is then transferred into the conical flask.
The glucose powder is then transferred into the conical flask.
With a clean spatula, a small amount of Sodium chloride powder is taken from the bottle.
The sodium chloride powder is then taken to the weighing balance and it is transferred into a clean butter paper. The weight of the Sodium chloride is adjusted to 0.5 g.
The butter paper with sodium chloride powder is then taken out from the weighing balance.
The sodium chloride powder is then transferred into the conical flask.
The sodium chloride powder is then transferred into the conical flask.
With a clean spatula, a small amount of phenol red powder is taken from the bottle.
The phenol red powder is then taken to the weighing balance and it is transferred into a clean butter paper. The weight of phenol red is adjusted to 1.8 mg.
The butter paper with phenol red powder is then taken out from the weighing balance.
The phenol red powder is then transferred into the conical flask.
The phenol red powder is then transferred into the conical flask.
The wash bottle containing distilled water is taken from the lab bench.
100 ml of distilled water is transferred into the measuring cylinder.
The wash bottle is then kept back on the lab bench and the measured distilled water is taken.
The distilled water is then transferred to the conical flask.
The measuring cylinder is then kept back on the lab bench.
The prepared broth is then taken from the lab bench.
The phenol red carbohydrate broth is then plugged with cotton.
It is then kept back on the lab bench and labeled as phenol red glucose broth.
The prepared broth is then taken from the lab bench.
The phenol red glucose broth is then kept in the Laminar Air Flow chamber.
Likewise phenol red maltose broth, phenol red sucrose broth, phenol red lactose broth and phenol red mannitol broth is prepared.
A screw caped tube is taken from the rack. The cotton plug is removed from the phenol red glucose broth.
The phenol red glucose broth is then taken from the lab bench.
The cap of the tube is opened and 5 ml of the broth is transferred into the tube.
The cap is then tightened and it is kept back in the rack. Another screw caped tube is taken from the rack.
The cap of the tube is opened and 5 ml of the broth is transferred into the tube.
The cap is then tightened and it is kept back in the rack.
One of the screw cap tubes containing phenol red glucose broth is taken from the rack.
The tube is then labeled as Glucose.
This tube serves as the “ Test” for the experimental analysis.
The tube is then kept back in the rack.A second screw caped tube with phenol red glucose broth is taken from the rack.
The tube is then labeled as Glucose “C” (ie., control).
This tube serves as the “control” for the experimental analysis.
The tube is then kept back in the rack. Another screw caped tube is then taken from the rack. The cotton plug of the phenol red lactose broth is then removed.
The phenol red lactose broth is taken from the LAF.
The cap of the tube is opened and 5 ml of the phenol red lactose broth is transferred into the tube.
The tube is then kept back in the rack. Another screw caped tube is then taken from the rack.
The cap of the tube is opened and 5 ml of phenol red lactose broth is transferred to the tube. The cap of the tube is then tightened.
The cap of the tube is opened and 5 ml of phenol red lactose broth is transferred to the tube. The cap of the tube is then tightened.
One of the screw cap tubes containing phenol red lactose broth is taken from the rack.
The tube is then labeled as lactose.
This tube serves as the “Test” for the experimental analysis.
The tube is then kept back in the rack.A second screw caped tube with phenol red lactose broth is taken from the rack.
The tube is then labeled as Lactose “C”.
This tube serves as the “control” for the experimental analysis.
The tube is then kept back in the rack.
Similarly Phenol red maltose broth, phenol red sucrose broth and phenol red mannitol broth (both control and test) was transferred to respective test tubes.
The prepared carbohydrate media were then arranged in the LAF table.
One of the phenol red glucose broth is then taken from the rack.
A durham tube is then taken from the beaker.
The Durham tube is then transferred aseptically into the phenol red glucose broth.
Similarly durham tubes were placed in all the phenol red carbohydrate broths.
The prepared carbohydrates need to be sterilized in an autoclave.
The knobs of autoclave is then unscrewed.
The lid of the autoclave is then opened.
The phenol red carbohydrate broth is then taken from the LAF table.
It is then taken into the autoclave for sterilization.
The lid of the autoclave is then closed.
The knobs of autoclave are then tightened.
The carbohydrate solution is then kept in the autoclave at 115 degree celcius for 15 minutes.
After sterilization the knobs of autoclave is unscrewed.
The lid of the autoclave is then opened.
The sterilized carbohydrate broth is then taken out from the autoclave.
The sterilized carbohydrate broth is then kept in the LAF.
An inoculation loop is taken from the rack.
It is then heat sterilized in the blue flame of the Bunsen burner till red hot and then allowed to cool for some time.
The overnight culture of bacteria is taken from the rack.
The mouth of the tube is then heat sterilized and a loopful of culture is taken with the cooled sterile loop. The mouth of the tube is again heat sterilized and cotton is replaced.
The bacterial culture is then kept in the rack.
The phenol red glucose broth (Test) is then taken from the rack.

The mouth of the tube is then heat sterilized. The bacterial culture in the inoculation loop is then transferred into the phenol red carbohydrate broth. The mouth of the tube is again heat sterilized.
The inoculated phenol red glucose broth is then kept back in the rack.
Similarly the bacterial culture is aseptically inoculated into other phenol red carbohydrate broths (The control tubes are kept uninoculated).
The door of the incubator is then opened.
All the phenol red carbohydrate broths (both test and control) are then taken from the LAF.

The phenol red carbohydrate broth is then kept in the incubator and the door of the incubator is closed. The phenol red carbohydrate broths are then incubated at 37 degree celcius for 24 hours and after incubation the tubes are taken out from the incubator.
The possible fermentation reactions that can happen during the incubation are as shown.
After incubation the carbohydrate fermentation tubes are placed in the LAF.
The respective fermentation reaction done by the bacterial culture was noted. By comparing the observed result with the standard, the fermentation result was found to be that of Escherichia coli.
